headline: Cellulose-responsive gene with developmental regulation and transcription factor dependencies
one_paragraph_summary:
This gene exhibits strong upregulation in response to cellulose and complex plant biomass substrates, with expression levels reaching 144-356 TPM compared to baseline levels of 3-50 TPM on simple sugars or under starvation conditions.
  • Expression is dramatically dependent on transcription factors XLR-1, CLR-1, and CLR-2, showing 18-fold reduction in xlr-1 knockouts
  • Shows clear developmental regulation during sexual development in Neurospora crassa, peaking at mid-stage perithecia formation
  • Exhibits substrate specificity, with highest response to mixed-linkage glucan and crystalline cellulose
  • Strongly repressed by sucrose, indicating carbon catabolite repression
The consistent cellulose-responsive expression pattern and transcription factor dependencies strongly suggest this gene encodes a cellulase or cellulose-degrading enzyme critical for plant biomass utilization.

topics.headline: Strong cellulose and plant biomass induction with transcription factor dependencies
topics.one_sentence_summary: The gene shows dramatic upregulation (3-220 fold) in response to cellulose, plant straws, and complex polysaccharides, with this response being dependent on the CLR-1, CLR-2, and XLR-1 transcription factors that regulate plant cell wall degradation pathways.

topics.headline: Developmental regulation during sexual reproduction and conidiation
topics.one_sentence_summary: Expression increases progressively during sexual development in Neurospora crassa, peaking during mid-stage perithecia formation, and shows highest levels in fresh conidia that decrease during germination, indicating roles in both sexual and asexual developmental processes.

topics.headline: Carbon source-specific regulation with sucrose repression
topics.one_sentence_summary: The gene shows strong upregulation on starch-derived substrates and is dramatically repressed by sucrose compared to other carbon sources, demonstrating carbon catabolite repression and involvement in alternative carbon metabolism pathways.

topics.headline: Regulatory pathway interactions affecting expression levels
topics.one_sentence_summary: Expression is modulated by multiple regulatory pathways including the SREBP pathway (sah-2 dependence), iron homeostasis (ve-1 interaction), and shows strain-dependent differences, indicating complex multilevel transcriptional control.
